header.title: The Scroll of Set, November 1976
keywords: Book of Coming Forth by Night

central_thesis: The core philosophical tenet presented is "Individualistic Collectivism," which posits that Setians pursue unique paths of self-deification and magical advancement ("Setamorphosis") while operating within the collective framework of the Temple of Set. This structure fosters mutual support and the sharing of diverse individual expressions of Setian philosophy, all aimed at a common, if individually interpreted, ultimate purpose, as guided by The Book of Coming Forth by Night.

structure_content.summary: Discusses the initiative to create personalized greeting cards for Setians, fostering community identity and expression for various occasions.

structure_content.chapter_title: Profile: L. Dale Seago, Magister Templi IV° and Councillor
structure_content.summary: Provides a biographical sketch of a foundational Temple of Set member, detailing his background in the Church of Satan, military service, and crucial roles in the Temple's early organizational structure and leadership.

Introduces and elaborates on a core Setian philosophy explaining the balance between individual magical pursuit and collective organizational purpose, using the metaphor of 'spokes' (individual paths) and 'rim' (the Temple's shared goal).

structure_content.chapter_title: Editorial: The True Flavor of the Setian Philosophy
structure_content.summary: Explores the diverse nature of Setian philosophy, the role of The Scroll of Set in fostering communal sharing of individual insights, and the importance of mutual support for magical growth and 'Setamorphosis' across different degrees of initiation.
A brief update on a legal matter involving a prominent Setian, Magistra Lilith Sinclair, indicating the community's engagement with current events.
Reports on a new California law allowing 'living wills,' reflecting a Setian interest in self-determination and legal/social awareness.

A poetic narrative describing a personal, internal magical journey or quest for knowledge and transformation, involving encounters with mystical forces and an ultimate return to the 'man in the tower'.

A complementary poem elaborating on themes of seeking esoteric knowledge, confronting change, and navigating an initiatory path, personifying the 'vulture' as a guiding figure in the 'Land of Carrion'.

key_concepts.definition: The unique and individually interpreted application of principles derived from The Book of Coming Forth by Night, leading to personal magical evolution and self-deification.

The foundational socio-magical structure of the Temple of Set, wherein individual Setians (spokes) pursue unique paths of self-deification and knowledge within a unifying collective purpose (rim) provided by the Temple. This necessitates both autonomous exploration and cooperative communal engagement.
The process of magical advancement, self-development, and ultimately, self-deification pursued by Setians, as implied by the goals of Setian philosophy.

The overarching organization that provides the 'rim' or unifying purpose and structure for individual Setian paths, intended to be a vehicle for collective magical advancement and support, distinct from pure individualism.
Sub-groups or local 'squads' within the Temple of Set, serving as smaller units for communal interaction and the practical application of 'Individualistic Collectivism'.

key_concepts.term: The Book of Coming Forth by Night
key_concepts.definition: A foundational Setian text, serving as the definitional source for Set and the philosophical basis for individual interpretation and application of Setian principles.
Hierarchical ranks within the Temple of Set, signifying progression in magical understanding and responsibility, with emphasis on higher degrees supporting lower ones for collective growth.

practical_system.description: The 'practical system' articulated is primarily philosophical and organizational, guiding individual magical development within a communal framework. It involves the active and individualized interpretation and application of Set's definition from The Book of Coming Forth by Night (leading to 'Setamorphosis'). The Temple of Set, through its Pylons and The Scroll, provides the necessary 'rim' or collective support, fostering an environment where diverse individual 'roads' (magical paths) can flourish through sharing, mutual encouragement, and constructive criticism, without prescribing specific ritual forms. The emphasis is on internal transformation and the acquisition of knowledge.

relevant_quotes.text: There is no natural-born Setian; they are either graduates or converts. Each is sure of the ultimate, yet the ultimate is not expressed in the same generic terminology by any two Setians.

Collectivism, yes. They are all heading for the same goal, the same purpose - the Temple of Set. Individualistic, yes. Each Setian is aiming for the same purpose, the same goal, but down different roads.
The spokes are the roads, and the rim is the goal: the rim that binds all the spokes together.
Set has defined himself in the Book of Coming Forth by Night, but each of us has a different application of this definition.

The "true flavor of Setian philosophy", then, is anything that will help Setians grow magically, broaden their world-view, and help them to cope with problems of day-to-day life, including our survival as Setians and Setamorphosis.
The sky is a door to Evermore If you ever seek to be On a quest of knowledge, Of learning which sails on endlessly.

critical_analysis.relevance: This collection of articles is crucial for understanding the early philosophical and operational foundations of the Temple of Set, particularly its unique 'Individualistic Collectivism.' It delineates the Setian path as distinct from prior LHP movements by emphasizing individual self-deification (Setamorphosis) within a supportive, structured collective rather than pure individualism or strict hierarchy. The content illustrates the nascent community's efforts to define its identity, foster internal communication, and promote the magical growth of its members, offering insight into the practical application of Setian theory.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary audience is internal to the Temple of Set: initiates across various degrees, Pylon leaders, and prospective members seeking to understand its ethos. Additionally, researchers of Western Esotericism, modern occultism, and Left Hand Path organizations would find it valuable for contextualizing the development of Setianism post-LaVeyan Satanism.
